awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RUI: Prediction of a Red Nova Outburst in the Star KIC 9832227
awd_abstract_narration:
Novae are stars that brighten dramatically almost overnight.  The investigators predict that the star KIC9832227 will become a nova early in the year 2022 with an uncertainty of about six months.  This star has been identified as a binary (two stars orbiting each other), with the two stars practically touching.  The period of revolution of the two stars is decreasing in a manner similar to that of another star which did become a nova; the research team predicts that in 2022 they will actually merge to become one star, emitting an enormous amount of energy.  The team plans to study the star further using the Hubble Space Telescope, the Very Long Baseline Array, and several other telescopes.  They will determine the properties of the two stars and monitor the changing period of revolution.  They will also test models for how stars merge.  They will collaborate with educators to produce education materials, consistent with science standards, for 6-12 grade students and teachers.  Undergraduates at their two institutions will be involved in the research.

The investigators determined that the period of revolution of KIC9832227 was decreasing in an exponential manner similar to an earlier nova, V1309 Sco.  Archival research enabled researchers to determine that the period of this earlier nova also decreased exponentially.  The team has considered other factors, such as additional companion stars, that could have caused the period change.  They propose to monitor the period changes with small telescopes.  They will also study the system further using large telescopes with spectrographs to rule out faint, as yet undiscovered, companion stars.  Most novae have undergone previous mass loss, and they are proposing to use infrared and coronographic studies to detect the effects of dust around the star.

por.por_cntn:
Summary

 

Contact binary stars are pairs of stars orbiting so closely they share a common atmosphere. Although one in five hundred sunlike stars have contact companions, there is no consensus on how they form, evolve, or die. The contact binary V1309 Sco was found to die abruptly in a luminous red nova outburst. Prior to the outburst its orbital period was found to be rapidly decreasing at an accelerating rate. Observations of the contact binary KIC 9832227 were found to show analogous changes in its orbital period, leading to the prediction it might soon end in a luminous red nova as well. The project proposed to follow up on this prediction with the goal of shedding light on the evolution of contact binary stars.

 

Intellectual Merit

 

Intensive observations of KIC 9832227 were pursued with a variety of techniques to define its properties more fully. However, a re-evaluation of archival data showed the initial conclusion of monotonically decreasing period was incorrect (invalidating the prediction of an imminent explosion).

 

As an alternative (and more comprehensive) approach, quantitative models of formation, evolution, and death were developed.

 

Formation: A two-step process (interaction of a new binary with the protostellar disk within which it formed followed by torques exerted by a modest wind flowing out along magnetic field lines) was found sufficient to explain key statistical properties of contact binary stars (the range of primary star masses and the frequency with which they occur).

 

Evolution: Evolution controlled by the gradual nuclear evolution of the primary star (conserving total mass and angular momentum) was computed. This assumption allowed determination of the rate of transfer of mass from the secondary to the primary star and hence to compute the evolution of the system over time. Transfer from the secondary star leads to a larger orbit, one with room for the primary star to grow. Theoretical plots of how contact binary orbits increase with time while the ratio of secondary to primary mass decreases were found to be consistent with data analyzed from the Kepler spacecraft catalog of binary stars.

 

Death: The precise circumstance in which a system ceases to be stable to gradual mass transfer were computed. The increasing size of the primary as it exhausts its hydrogen fuel source eventually makes it impossible for the companion star to keep it synchronously rotating. Consequently, the pair begins to spiral back together at a rapid but fixed rate. It is estimated this stage lasts about 10,000 years before the final death spiral is reached. Seven stars in the galactic bulge were identified that appear to be currently in this stage.

 

Broader Impacts

 

Combinations of the model components can be used in the future to compare against the statistical properties of contact binary.stars (the distribution of orbital periods and mass ratios) in catalogs of stars of various ages. The magnetic torque functions found to work for contact binaries can also be applied to evolution of other, more exotic types of binary stars (cataclysmic variables and low mass X-ray binaries).

 

Research opportunities were given to seven undergraduate students, most of whom have now moved on to graduate studies in physics and astronomy.

 

A documentary, “Luminous”, was filmed following the progress of the research through the initial prediction of the merger of KIC 9832227 and subsequent developments. That has now been edited into a 90-minute final product highlighting the nature of the scientific process. It has been shown at numerous film festivals (including ones in France and Australia), at amateur astronomy clubs, and in introductory science classes.
